title: I inherited half of a business. It's in debt with phantom tax and no money can be exchanged to buy me out. what can I do?
question: Older, business savy brother runs and owns other half. He says company losing money for years, yet he lives very well. In debt, with a phantom tax that Surprise? he never even knew about. He cannot buy me out or debt will become due. I receive nothing from this business. What should I do?
answers: You should find out the true facts about the business before you take any action. Contact a business attorney and as a 50% partner, member or shareholder you are entitled to look at the books, profit and loss, balance sheets etc. Then after you have the facts an attorney can file legal action to Dissolve the Corporation or partnership and distribute ther assets.

You should meet with a lawyer who both understands California corporate law and tax law. California corporate law governs corporations, partnerships and LLCs, so no matter how it is operated under state law, that lawyer will be able to advise you about your rights to information and your rights to determine the business's future, e.g., whether you can force an involuntary dissolution.

You need to get together with a business lawyer in your area to see what your options are. If this business is a general partnership, you can force the partnership to dissolve, pay its debts, and distribute money (if any) to the partners. If this is a corporation, there are options for doing the same thing, but you need to go over the details with the lawyer.
As a 50% owner of the business, you have the right to access the books right away. Exercise that right to review as soon as you can to see where the money is coming from (if any) and where it is going to or has gone. Again, though, you need a business lawyer in your area that you can trust.
